description:
Equus asinus, commonly known as the donkey or ass, is a member of the horse family Equidae. It is a domesticated equine species that originated in the wild ancestors found in Africa. Donkeys are medium-sized equines, typically standing between 36 to 54 inches tall at the shoulder and weighing between 350 to 500 pounds.

Anatomically, donkeys have large, erect ears, a thick, shaggy coat, and a distinctive braying call. They have sturdy, muscular bodies and are known for their sure-footedness and ability to thrive in harsh, arid environments. Donkeys are herbivores, primarily grazing on grasses, shrubs, and other vegetation.

Behaviorally, donkeys are known for their intelligence, docility, and hardiness. They are often used as pack animals, for transportation, and in agricultural work due to their strength and adaptability to various terrains and climates. Donkeys have played an important role in human history, serving as valuable working animals in many cultures around the world.
